abstracts.cdata!:
The overall rating of the project is
            satisfactory, and sustainability is likely. While the
            ratings for both the Bank, and the Borrower's
            performances are satisfactory, project preparation was
            unsatisfactory, for, although project design adequately
            addressed primary education issues existing at the time, the
            design however, was insufficiently comprehensive. The
            lessons learned convey, that as a result of this primary
            education project - under which several studies addressed
            the weaknesses in the system - the Government declared
            Education Sector Development as a priority, adopting the
            project into its recurrent budget, for future operations
            continuity. This was conducive to a shift from project
            specific, to sector wide issues, addressing all levels of
            education, thus future operations should capitalize on the
            government commitments to sector policy/strategy development
            in education. A strong working partnership with the school
            management was developed, ensuring input delivery to the
            system. However, implementation lacked detailed costs, and
            financial planning, hence, future projects should consider a
            time-bound activity level implementation plan, with all
            terms of reference for consultants, studies, or training,
            drafted before effectiveness. In addition, implementation,
            and outcome indicators should be divided, to attain
            quantifiable targets, and, financial implications agreed at
            the earliest.

5079176.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Rural development,Urban development,Human development

abstracts.cdata!:
The project supports the
            Government's development plans for primary education
            for the period 1992-97. It aims to improve the quality of
            instructional inputs in primary schools and increase student
            educational achievement levels by pursuing the following
            objectives: (a) introducing a new system for the training of
            primary school teachers in order to improve the quality and
            relevance of teacher training and increase the number of
            teachers with professional certification; (b) improving the
            quality, availability, and efficient use of educational
            facilities and resources for both teaching and learning; and
            (c) strengthening the planning and management of education
            to enable the Government to develop policies and implement
            programs to improve the cost-effectiveness of its
            expenditures on education.
